height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Apr 2021 15:26:16 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/608585c83f0560001881be90?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"cdaf3389d091be86f03d19df8c0c0ef1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-54-550_ae5d6bdb8ea36f05.webp","destWidth":1759,"destHeight":1320,"sourceBytes":73288,"destBytes":73288,"author":"insider@insider.com (Connor Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608585cc0da8f40018033549?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn76@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-712_62e40a91c8e77aaa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ytDYivqxyqw:6vUzC9Zv6KI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn17@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-02-424_9b4c88228fc7b6c2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ytDYivqxyqw:6vUzC9Zv6KI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn27@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-58-182_dca9cb5f34803e5c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ytDYivqxyqw:6vUzC9Zv6KI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn91@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-27-03-316_c75df4ba17b8b677.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ytDYivqxyqw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn67@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-58-658_d4e7813ab4d0c42d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596206},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"From Trump to Frank: A timeline of MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell's eventful career so far","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/timeline-mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-political-history-so-far-2021-3","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6083dc0d1d0b54001913dbcd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Frank Mike Lindell\" height=\"680\" width=\"1360\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mike Lindell held a livestreaming marathon to celebrate the launch of Frank.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Frank</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Mike Lindell, CEO of MyPillow, became a recognizable political figure during Trump&#39;s term.</li>\n<li>His latest venture, the social-media platform Frank, has launched. </li>\n<li>Here&#39;s a brief timeline of Lindell&#39;s most notable career moments.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Mike Lindell, chief executive of MyPillow, rose into the national political spotlight seemingly overnight as he was pulled into President Donald Trump&#39;s inner circle. </p><p>He&#39;s been making news since at least 2009, though, when he launched MyPillow in Carver, Minnesota. During MyPillow&#39;s first few years, Lindell&#39;s name popped up often in <a href=\"https://www.startribune.com/mypillows-headed-for-the-playboy-mansion/125114744/\">The Minneapolis Star Tribune</a>, usually in <a href=\"https://www.startribune.com/c-j-mypillow-employees-got-unrestful-lindell-tirade/248663461/\">gossip columns</a>.</p><p>Nine years ago, Lindell told a reporter at <a href=\"http://chaska.uber.matchbin.net/pages/full_story/push?article-No+rest+for+Carver-s+pillow+czar%20&id=168721822182\">The Chaska Herald</a> that his company was growing at a rate of about 10% per month, with expected annual sales of $10 million.  &#34;Within three years, one-fifth of the world&#39;s population will be sleeping on MyPillow. That is my goal,&#34; he said at the time. </p><p>By the time Donald Trump started his run for office, Lindell had become a recognizable face around the country. He appeared in his own MyPillow ads, which often ran on Fox News. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5da09b3f4af90938077de372?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mike Lindell MyPillow my pillow \" height=\"595\" width=\"1057\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell appears in a MyPillow TV commercial.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.mypillow.com/\" target=\"_blank\">MyPillow</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Trump invited him to Trump Tower on August 15, 2016, marking their first meeting, according to <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2018/11/03/politics/donald-trump-mike-lindell-mypillow-midterms/index.html\">CNN</a>. Now, about five years later, Lindell is as well known for his political advocacy as for his pillow business.</p><p>Since Trump lost the presidential election in November, Lindell&#39;s pushed several questionable theories about election fraud. In the wake of the January 6 Capitol insurrection, Lindell questioned whether the rioters had been Antifa plants.</p><p>More recently, MyPillow has launched a counter-lawsuit <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-mypillow-dominion-lawsuit-trump-voter-fraud-2021-4\">against Dominion for $1.6 billion</a>. On the retail front, many companies, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-mypillow-costco-stopped-selling-products-retailer-sales-2021-4\">including Costco</a>, have stopped stocking MyPillow&#39;s products, Lindell told Insider.</p><p>Here&#39;s a brief timeline of Lindell&#39;s years in the national spotlight alongside Trump. We&#39;ll update this article from time to time. </p><h2>On July 19, 2017, Lindell appeared with Trump at the White House</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60072f8d660f6c0018349ce6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump my pillow mike lindell\" height=\"1643\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Michael Lindell with President Trump at the White House in 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Alex Brandon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>During Trump&#39;s term, Lindell, a major Republican donor, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-founder-ceo-mypillow-donald-trump-ally-2020-8\">often appeared alongside</a> the president. He was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-founder-ceo-mypillow-donald-trump-ally-2020-8#lindell-is-a-major-trump-donor-and-has-appeared-at-campaign-rallies-and-white-house-press-briefings-to-boost-the-president-3\">invited</a> to the White House for a 2017 event during <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-made-in-america-2017-7?inline-read-more\">&#34;Made In America&#34;</a> week, because his pillows are made in the US. </p><h2>On October 11, 2019, Trump praised Lindell</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d9fed2b4af9095c5c61df82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Donald Trump Minneapolis rally\" height=\"2252\" width=\"3229\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trump holds a campaign rally in Minneapolis, Minnesota, in October 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Leah Millis/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>During Trump&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-hosts-first-rally-in-minneapolis-since-impeachment-inquiry-began-2019-10\">first political rally</a> after the House began <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/impeachment-inquiry-into-trump-explained-in-30-seconds-2019-10\">an impeachment inquiry</a>, the president praised Lindell. Trump was speaking in Minnesota, where Lindell grew up. </p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"none\">-Daniel Dale  (@ddale8) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1182465907689431042?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 11, 2019</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><h2>On January 7, 2021, Lindell spread misinformation about Antifa&#39;s involvement in the Capitol riots</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604ab36ef196be0018bef035?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Capitol attack riot\" height=\"1334\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A pro-Trump mob broke into the US Capitol on January 6, 2021 to disrupt the Electoral Vote Certification.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Brent Stirton/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the days after the January 6 Capitol insurrection, Lindell took to Twitter and Parler to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/my-pillow-parler-users-blame-antifa-us-capitol-riots-2021-1\">share a 7-minute video</a>, in which he said the rioters may have been &#34;plants.&#34; </p><p>&#34;First of all, the riots you&#39;re seeing on TV - that&#39;s a joke,&#34; Lindell told followers in a video posted to Facebook, Twitter, and Parler.</p><h2>On January 15, 2021, Lindell&#39;s White House meeting notes made news</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/604cee0710c8760018b93182?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Lindell White House Notes AP\" height=\"3313\" width=\"4970\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell waits to go into the West Wing of the White House on Friday, Jan. 15, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Gerald Herbert/AP Photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>On January 15, Jabin Botsford, a photographer at The Washington Post, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-mypillow-ceo-discuss-insurrection-act-photographed-notes-2021-1\">photographed</a> Lindell carrying notes into an Oval Office meeting with Trump. </p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Jabin Botsford  (@jabinbotsford) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1350186100564905985?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">January 15, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>Lindell was walking with a coffee in one hand and his notes in the other, when they were captured. In part, they <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-mypillow-ceo-discuss-insurrection-act-photographed-notes-2021-1\">read</a>: &#34;Insurrection Act now as a result of the assault on the... martial law if necessary up the first hint of any...&#34;</p><h2>On January 21, 2021, Insider published a profile of Lindell</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6007315ee3d62500185fd2ea?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mypillow ceo mike lindell profile 2x1\" height=\"1292\" width=\"2584\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell with a MyPillow pillow.\n<p class=\"copyright\">MyPillow; Chris J Ratcliffe/Getty Images; Stephen Maturen/Getty Images; Samantha Lee/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Lindell continued supporting Trump throughout the final days of his presidency, even as other <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/all-the-businesses-cutting-ties-with-the-trump-organization-2021-1\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"7ddfdb39c439e9d7913335996642c4e9\">corporate allies abandoned</a> the president.</p><p>In January, Insider&#39;s Kate Taylor spoke with Lindell. &#34;I&#39;m not backing down on these machines that stole our election,&#34; he told <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/my-pillow-ceo-mike-lindell-trump-final-days-2021-1\">Insider</a>.</p><h2>On January 23, 2021, big box stores pulled MyPillow from shelves</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ff7717c6d61c10019cce3c4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"bed bath &#38; beyond\" height=\"683\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Bed Bath &#38; Beyond.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Hennessy/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Bed Bath &#38; Beyond, Kohl&#39;s, and other large US retailers said they&#39;d <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillows-lost-partnerships-kohls-bed-bath-beyond-problems-2021-1\">ended their partnerships</a> with MyPillow because of poor sales. Costco said it would <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/costco-selling-mypillow-despite-ceo-false-claims-election-fraud-2021-1\">continue selling</a> the pillows. </p><p>&#34;We have contractual commitments to MyPillow that we intend to honor, as we seek to do with all of our suppliers,&#34; a Costco representative told <a href=\"https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Costco-keep-selling-MyPillow-CEO-Mike-Lindell-15887403.php\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"2d5c527cee252e4ac4e139e06b13e9e3\">SFGate</a> at the time.  </p><p>Lindell said he was skeptical of companies&#39; decisions to cut ties soon after news broke that he was facing a legal threat from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dominion-voting-machines-mypillow-mike-lindell-election-voter-fraud-trump-2021-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dominion-voting-machines-mypillow-mike-lindell-election-voter-fraud-trump-2021-1\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"bb3834b9b4f9e1a65564dd9f4ca97829\">voting-technology company Dominion,</a> linked to his propagation of baseless voter fraud theories. </p><h2>On January 26, 2021, Lindell was permanently banned from Twitter</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60073174e3d62500185fd2ec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mike lindell my pillow\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell speaks to the crowd with Pulse founder Nick Hall in Minnesota.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Adam Bettcher/WireImage</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Lindell had sent Twitter messages asking Trump to impose <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-permanently-banned-from-twitter-2021-1\">&#34;martial law&#34;</a> in the seven states where the president planned to contest election results. Lindell also said some Georgia voters should &#34;go to prison&#34; as a punishment for Biden&#39;s win. </p><h2>On February 2, 2021, a Newsmax anchor walked off during a Lindell interview</h2><p>The pro-Trump network Newsmax <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/newsmax-cuts-off-mypillow-ceo-mic-election-conspiracies-video-2021-2\">cut off</a> Lindell&#39;s microphone, after he started amplifying bogus conspiracy theories about the 2020 election while on the air.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Jason Campbell  (@JasonSCampbell) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1356719881564086272?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 2, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>The segment had been about Twitter removing Lindell&#39;s account, along with the MyPillow account. Lindell opened the conversation by saying: &#34;We have 100% proof&#34; of voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election.</p><p>But Bob Sellers, a Newsmax anchor, cut him off. </p><p>&#34;Mike, you&#39;re talking about machines, that we at Newsmax have not been able to verify any of those kinds of allegations,&#34; he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/newsmax-cuts-off-mypillow-ceo-mic-election-conspiracies-video-2021-2\">said</a>. </p><p>A few moments later, Sellers hopped out of his chair, leaving the set as Lindell spoke. </p><h2>On February 22, 2021, Dominion Voting Systems sued Lindell</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60242ef867d1e300113c5508?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mike lindell trump\" height=\"2667\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Trump listens as Lindell speaks at the White House\n<p class=\"copyright\">MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Dominion Voting Systems <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/dominion-sues-mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-election-fraud-claims-voting-2021-2\">sued</a> both MyPillow and Lindell, seeking damages of more than $1.3 billion. In weeks prior, the company had said Lindell was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-election-fraud-conspiracy-trump-dominion-voting-2021-2\">&#34;begging to be sued.&#34;  </a>MyPillow, has since launched a counter-lawsuit against Dominion for $1.6 billion.</p><p> </p><h2>On February 5, 2021, Lindell aired his own documentary about election fraud</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6007302f660f6c0018349ce9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Lindell my pillow\" height=\"1653\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell cheers as Trump speaks to supporters.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In early February, Lindell <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillow-made-three-hour-film-about-election-trump-2021-2\">appeared</a> on The Revival Channel on YouTube to announce a documentary, &#34;Absolute Proof,&#34; he&#39;d made in support of his baseless claims of issues in the 2020 election.</p><p>He bought airtime on One America News Network to air the documentary. The network ran a 90-second statement before airing the film.</p><p>The movie in March earned Lindell a Razzie nomination for worst actor, according to <a href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/365-days-dolittle-sias-music-top-razzie-awards-nominations\">The Hollywood Reporter</a>. </p><h2>Lindell launched a social-media site focused on free speech</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60242e9bcca90200129b786b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mike lindell white house\" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Lindell at the White House.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Lindell in March said he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-social-media-site-platform-twitter-ban-2021-3\">planned to launch</a> his own social-media site, which would be a cross between Twitter and YouTube. </p><p>&#34;It&#39;s not like anything you&#39;ve ever seen,&#34; he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mypillow-ceo-mike-lindell-to-launch-site-combining-twitter-youtube-2021-3\">told</a> Insider. &#34;It&#39;s all about being able to be vocal again and not to be walking on eggshells.&#34;</p><p dir=\"ltr\">By mid-April, the site&#39;s name had changed from Vocl to Frank. Lindell also said the site planned to bar <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-access-social-media-frank-block-swearing-porn-blasphemy-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-access-social-media-frank-block-swearing-porn-blasphemy-2021-4&source=gmail&ust=1619339802368000&usg=AFQjCNHfG8TPKmKO693wRvWf3Vlu416EOAWf3Vlu416EOA\">swearing, porn, and death threats</a>.</p><p dir=\"ltr\">After <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-mypillow-social-media-frank-vip-launch-access-delay-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-mypillow-social-media-frank-vip-launch-access-delay-2021-4&source=gmail&ust=1619339802368000&usg=AFQjCNGzceOK1HBHcDC9B1P7FC4ognviOQP7FC4ognviOQ\">a delayed launch</a>, the site got off to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-social-media-site-frank-launch-day-errors-issues-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-social-media-site-frank-launch-day-errors-issues-2021-4&source=gmail&ust=1619339802368000&usg=AFQjCNFbBJ6IXmqAmZbYW6IOrdcJz_JbwQIOrdcJz_JbwQ\">a rocky start</a>, initially displaying an error message. Lindell said the website <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-social-media-site-frank-launch-day-errors-issues-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-social-media-site-frank-launch-day-errors-issues-2021-4&source=gmail&ust=1619339802368000&usg=AFQjCNFbBJ6IXmqAmZbYW6IOrdcJz_JbwQIOrdcJz_JbwQ\">was facing</a> a &#34;massive attack against it.&#34; </p><p>To celebrate the launch, Lindell hosted <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-frank-a-thon-highlights-2021-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.businessinsider.com/mike-lindell-frank-a-thon-highlights-2021-4&source=gmail&ust=1619339802368000&usg=AFQjCNFBX7CdeNHTJgf4kuDYIz1iVPxODgDYIz1iVPxODg\">a marathon livestream</a>, which he called Frankathon.</p><p> </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Shalvey)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6083dc0d1d0b54001913dbcd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn40@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-59-037_f70f7e75cd3ebaa0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5da09b3f4af90938077de372?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn55@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-56-474_cd901bf4617195e4.webp","https://i.insider.com/60072f8d660f6c0018349ce6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn51@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-59-814_45b7cde8eaa3abb3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d9fed2b4af9095c5c61df82?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn92@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-00-234_5af23641ae2fe154.webp","https://i.insider.com/604ab36ef196be0018bef035?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn8@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-55-104_5087a7a25c71294e.webp","https://i.insider.com/604cee0710c8760018b93182?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn4@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-01-112_c553b63a098dd8a4.webp","https://i.insider.com/6007315ee3d62500185fd2ea?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn56@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-55-231_daa71bba4db17fab.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ff7717c6d61c10019cce3c4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn19@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-56-655_3c4330a304b11e05.webp","https://i.insider.com/60073174e3d62500185fd2ec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn11@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-57-088_7fc38ca8678aa384.webp","https://i.insider.com/60242ef867d1e300113c5508?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn64@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-265_0a6e58d97787f95d.webp","https://i.insider.com/6007302f660f6c0018349ce9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn17@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-27-00-152_7f8203867382a8d2.webp","https://i.insider.com/60242e9bcca90200129b786b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-01-254_8953bd2fee9718a2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Y_o-dmJZ66I:8-VXkW1yAds:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn47@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-03-090_1a68c54e44e79b33.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Y_o-dmJZ66I:8-VXkW1yAds:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn76@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-56-113_7b7ed18858e4c7ba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Y_o-dmJZ66I:8-VXkW1yAds:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn5@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-01-566_a7d49baee95b57aa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Y_o-dmJZ66I":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn4@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-56-092_79eef4ed31370390.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596243},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"For one small restaurant operator in Columbus, Ohio, the labor shortage means returning to pre-pandemic service is 'unfathomable'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ohio-brewery-owner-says-labor-shortage-causes-unfathomable-situation-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082f6801041d50019f2df1b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wolf breweing\" height=\"853\" width=\"1279\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing in Columbus, Ohio. Photo provided courtesy of the company.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Provided by Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The co-founder of Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing in Columbus, Ohio, can&#39;t find workers to fill open roles.</li>\n<li>To get back to 2019 levels, he&#39;d need at least 10 new hires, but there&#39;s a dearth of applicants.</li>\n<li>His case is just one of the many businesses facing a labor shortage in the US. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The co-founder of <a href=\"https://www.wolfsridgebrewing.com/\">Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing</a> in Columbus, Ohio, is tired.</p><p>More than a year ago, Bob Szuter laid off most of his 80-person staff, leaving just 15 core workers to continue operating the restaurant and brewery. He wasn&#39;t sure if his business would survive, and he had two young girls at home.</p><p>The wholesale side, which once comprised just a quarter of the business, now kept the brewery going, along with carryout and delivery operations, as the restaurant dining room remained closed because of the coronavirus pandemic. </p><p>Once businesses in Ohio were allowed to re-open last year, he had new challenge: operating under COVID-19 restrictions, like social distancing, capacity rules, and mask guidelines put forth by the state.</p><p>At first, customers were supportive, but as the pandemic has continued, they&#39;ve become less enthusiastic -- and more aggressive -- about not wanting to wearing a mask to the bathroom or being unable to get a reservation because the restaurant has met its capacity limit. </p><p>His latest hurdle? Finding workers to fill open positions.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/economic-outlook-labor-market-recovery-hiring-unemployment-crisis-stimulus-2021-4\">Businesses across the country have been in a scramble</a> to hire workers as more Americans receive the COVID-19 vaccine, and states begin lifting restrictions on restaurants, stores and other venues. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-subway-struggle-to-find-workers-forcing-changes-2021-4\">Fast-food chains</a>, among other businesses, have said they&#39;re in need of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fast-food-struggles-to-hire-as-demand-soars-us-economy-roars-2021-4\">thousands of workers</a> to fill open roles.</p><p>The unemployment rate remains elevated from pre-pandemic levels and millions of people are out of work, but still there&#39;s a shortage of applicants. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/unemployed-workers-arent-returning-to-the-labor-force-jobless-benefits-2021-4\">That&#39;s in part due to</a> unemployment benefits creating a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-unemployment-benefits-fuel-hiring-struggles-companies-say-2021-4\">disincentive to return to work</a>, a desire for higher wages in the restaurant industry, and the continued fear of getting sick with the virus. Plus, Szuter said, some of his former workers have left the industry after finding new roles during the pandemic.</p><p>For Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing, returning to pre-pandemic levels of serving a couple hundred people per night wouldn&#39;t be doable with the current staff, Szuter said. </p><p>&#34;It&#39;s almost good that the restrictions are still in place,&#34; he said. &#34;Once those restrictions come off, there&#39;s no way we could do that.&#34;</p><p><em><strong>Read more: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/business-owner-burnout-took-sabbatical-treat-anxiety-exhaustion-2021-4\">How a burned-out business owner took a one-month sabbatical to treat the anxiety and exhaustion of his always-on, entrepreneurial life</a></strong></em></p><p>Szuter started looking for more workers in November of 2020. </p><p>Since then, he&#39;s raised the minimum wage for his employees to at least $15 per hour. That&#39;s up from about $12 per hour that backroom staff, like the cooks, used to make and far more than Ohio&#39;s minimum wage of $8.80 per hour for non-tipped workers. He&#39;s added hiring bonuses of $250 to $300 for open positions like dish washers, too. </p><p>Still applicants for serving, cooking, and dish washing roles are lacking. He used to get half a dozen applications for a job opening, but now there&#39;s hardly a response. His general manager has resorted to scrolling through social media to find anyone reporting looking for work. </p><p>&#34;It&#39;s been a struggle,&#34; Szuter said. &#34;Just a lot of difficulty in getting people to even interview, and finding not even necessarily qualified candidates, but just candidates in general.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60831a7d1041d50019f2dff9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"wolf brewing\" height=\"1048\" width=\"1397\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing in Columbus, Ohio. Photo provided courtesy of the company.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Restaurant</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>After operating with a staff of about 45 for most of last year, he&#39;s now up to 68 employees. That includes about 10 new roles he had to fill to keep up with the growth from the wholesale side of the business. </p><p>His staff is working about 60-hour weeks, and they&#39;re feeling burned out, he said. The restaurant has cut back even further on its operations to account for the lack of workers. Pre-pandemic, Wolf&#39;s Ridge Brewing was open six days a week. Now, he&#39;s down to no lunch service and dinner just Thursday through Saturday. </p><p>He&#39;s currently looking for two to three backroom workers and then one or two servers to open up for a few more meals each week.</p><p>&#34;There&#39;s still an expectation from most people that things should just go right back to what they were in 2019,&#34; he said. &#34;That&#39;s just not where we are.&#34;</p><p>To get back to pre-pandemic operations, he&#39;d need at least 10 more workers, he said, &#34;and that&#39;s just unfathomable in this situation.&#34; </p><p>Some hospitality industry experts say hiring might be slow right now, but they expect that to change.</p><p>&#34;Unlike the little to no lead time the government gave businesses regarding reopening guidelines, workers planning on returning to hospitality will do so in phases and it won&#39;t happen overnight,&#34; Alice Cheng, the CEO of hospitality hiring company Culinary Agents, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/recent-observations-hospitalitys-job-market-alice-cheng?trk=public_profile_article_view\">wrote on Linkedin.</a> &#34;The gravitational pull of the hospitality industry will eventually prevail,&#34; she wrote.</p><p>Szuter is hoping that shift comes soon.</p><p>&#34;The biggest mental stressor for managers and myself is just trying to keep staff morale up and keep things as positive as we can,&#34; he said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/ohio-brewery-owner-says-labor-shortage-causes-unfathomable-situation-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"A Texas hospital is the first in the country to require COVID-19 vaccinations for its staff","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/texas-hospital-first-to-require-covid-vaccinations-for-staff-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60815e884becb800190f673f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"covid vaccine\" height=\"1356\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A medical assistant administers a COVID-19 vaccine dose to a woman at a clinic in Los Angeles on March 25, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/medical-assistant-floater-charlene-batas-administers-a-one-news-photo/1309200757?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Mario Tama/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A hospital system in Texas is now the first in the nation to mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for staff.</li>\n<li>Houston Methodist set a June 7 deadline for all employees to get vaccinated, a spokesperson said.</li>\n<li>So far, 89% of all 26,000 employees have complied and received a vaccine.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Houston Methodist system - made up of 26,000 employees across one medical center and six community hospitals - is the nation&#39;s first hospital system to require that all employees get vaccinated against the coronavirus. </p><p>Houston Methodist is mandating that all employees get vaccinated by June 7, a spokesperson confirmed to Insider. Managers were instructed to get fully vaccinated by April 15. </p><p>&#34;Mandating the vaccine was not a decision we made lightly, but science has proven that the COVID-19 vaccines are very safe and very effective. Like I say to everyone who asks-whether they are reporters, the public, patients or our employees, it is our sacred obligation to do everything possible to keep our patients safe,&#34; Dr. Marc Boom, president and CEO of Houston Methodist, said in an email to employees Friday, which Insider viewed.</p><p>&#34;By choosing to be vaccinated, you are leaders-showing our colleagues in health care what must be done to protect our patients, ourselves, our families and our communities,&#34; he continued.</p><p>Boom also said other hospitals in Texas will follow the lead of Houston Methodist. </p><p>So far, the mandate has been vastly successful, with 89% of all Houston Methodist employees having received the vaccine, Boom said in his email.</p><p>In March, before the mandate was instituted, the hospital system offered employees who got the vaccine a <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-vaccine-houston-hospital-500-dollars/\">$500 incentive</a>. </p><p>Since then and since requiring vaccination, some employees have pushed back. </p><p>After requiring that all employees receive the vaccine, Houston Methodist saw two managers leave. There are about 1,200 employees in management positions there.</p><p>An unnamed person who says they&#39;re an employee at Houston Methodist started a <a href=\"https://www.change.org/p/houston-methodist-covid-vaccine-should-not-be-mandatory-or-termination?use_react=false\">petition</a> to force the hospital to rescind its vaccine mandate. So far, it has more than 3,800 signatures. </p><p>&#34;Many employees are scared that they will lose their job or be forced to inject the vaccine into their body against their will to keep their jobs and feed their family,&#34; the petition says. &#34;We just want the power to choose for ourselves and not take this basic American right away from us! Please help our cause to fight for all the nurses, physical therapists, respiratory therapists, pharmacy staff, phlebotomists, etc.&#34;</p><p>Employees who do not get the vaccine have been warned they could be fired, Insider&#39;s Grace Dean <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/houston-hospital-covid-19-vaccine-fire-staff-employees-refuse-texas-2021-4\">reported</a>.</p><p>So far, more than 26% of the US population has been fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, according to <a href=\"https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/region/united-states\">data</a> published by Johns Hopkins University.</p><p><em>Have a news tip? Reach this reporter at ydzhanova@insider.com</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/bIfc40mmo2s\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Apr 2021 13:29:34 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60815e99354dde0018c068ca?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ae67efe75921f328c56ffde62ecd4486","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn96@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-54-540_d4d28fa16ab1ad1d.webp","destWidth":1807,"destHeight":1356,"sourceBytes":74574,"destBytes":74574,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/60815e884becb800190f673f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn24@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-59-663_c79510bdf201c5f1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn70@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-27-02-215_51610593d6c04ab3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn43@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-54-568_1af28e05f3924a6e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=bIfc40mmo2s:pVICCnK_UYk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn99@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-57-442_b371d5bb7d774e04.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/bIfc40mmo2s":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn44@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-26-58-609_7bafe171b1854eff.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596208},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"9 things every founder should cover in their business pitch to potential investors","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-founders-should-include-pitch-business-investors-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082d8691041d50019f2de23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman giving presentation\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Founders should specify what specific investment amount they need and how they intend to use it.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Morsa Images/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Martin Zwilling is CEO of Startup Professionals, a company that offers services to startup founders.</li>\n<li>These are the nine key bases he recommends all founders cover in their product pitches.</li>\n<li>They include having a clear focus, quantifying value, and showing a cost margin of at least 50%.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As a long-time adviser to entrepreneurs and an occasional <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/larry-alton/what-are-most-important-considerations-for-angel-investors.html\">angel investor</a>, I often see and hear innovative product <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/jeff-haden/how-to-pitch-18-steps-to-create-and-deliver-a-winn.html\">pitches</a> that sound exciting, but are missing one or more of the key business elements that investors deem critical for funding consideration.</p><p>We all hate to see your <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/larry-kim/4-things-learn-from-investor-rejection-letters.html\">proposal rejected</a>, when a bit more effort and homework could expedite your startup funding and rollout.</p><p>Of course, you can find these elements embodied in many of the business plan templates and tools out there, such as the <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/steve-blank/the-business-model-canvas.html\">Business Model Canvas</a>. But in addition, I&#39;ve always found it helpful to provide a simple checklist for new venture founders and new business owners to make sure they have covered all the key bases correctly, including the following:</p><h2>1. Define and focus on a single customer segment. </h2><p>The business proposals I see often target multiple unrelated segments, such as consumers, enterprises, and government. No new venture can muster the resources and expertise to attack all these opportunities concurrently, so I recommend a clear and quantified focus on one to maintain credibility.</p><h2>2. Quantify your value proposition for customers.</h2><p>&#34;Nice to have&#34; and &#34;improved usability&#34; are not value propositions that people spend money or endure change for. Quantification of value in terms of dollars or time saved is much more attractive. Social value, such as providing the latest fashion trend, are secondary but also important.</p><h2>3. Provide initial and long-term sources of revenue.</h2><p>&#34;Free&#34; is not an exciting business model for investor interest. Every business, including non-profits, need a viable source of revenue to cover the costs of operation and sustainability. The most attractive revenue model today for services is subscriptions; for products, it is sales and support.</p><h2>4. Show a cost margin of at least 50%.</h2><p>Projecting a low cost margin, with a commitment to low overhead and hard work, is not convincing. Investors know that operational and employee expenses are always higher than anticipated, not to mention customer acquisition costs, capital expenses, and ongoing competitive initiatives.</p><h2>5. Identify your intellectual property or &#34;secret sauce.&#34;</h2><p>Unfortunately, startups with an innovative product but no protection are quickly overrun by larger competitors with more resources. Competitor resources include larger cash assets, trained staffs, existing customers, and a known brand in the market. Patents are a good place for you to start.</p><h2>6. Specify a primary customer channel for sales.</h2><p>Today, the most common and successful channel for new ventures is e-commerce. Trying to distribute initially through wholesale and retail, as well as online, is very risky from an investor perspective. Other viable channels would include licensing, contracting, white-labeling, and services.</p><h2>7. Actions for a memorable customer experience.</h2><p>Modern customers are sensitive to the total customer relationship, including shopping, transaction, service, and support. You need to convince investors that you will excel in these areas, as well as attract more new customers, maintain existing customer loyalty, drive repeat business, and grow sales.</p><h2>8. Convince me that you understand your competition.</h2><p>I recommend that you pick your three major competitors and highlight your advantages over each, without degrading any of them. No investor will believe that you have no competition, or that you can succeed in a market already populated with dozens of competitors. Outline your key activities to win.</p><h2>9. Highlight the strengths of the entire team and partners.</h2><p>Most investors admit that they invest in the people as much as the solution. Make sure they understand why you and your team are the right people to make this business a success. The same applies to your advisers, your partner relationships, and your leadership activities in the industry.</p><p>After highlighting all these elements, don&#39;t forget to ask for the order. You need to specify what investment amount you need, how you intend to use it, and what percent of your equity you are willing to give up to get it.</p><p>Everyone needs to feel you are proposing a win-win opportunity. Use your passion and conviction, as well as these specifics, to make my day as well as yours.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-founders-should-include-pitch-business-investors-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a outbreak","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-pressured-to-donate-covid-19-vaccine-to-india-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608564e73f0560001881be7c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"biden second shot \" height=\"1031\" width=\"2063\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President-elect Joe Biden received his second dose COVID-19 vaccine shot in Newark, Delaware on January 11, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Public-health experts and physicians are urging the US to donate vaccine doses to India.</li>\n<li>India&#39;s COVID-19 surge is shattering world records. The country recorded 349,691 new cases Sunday.</li>\n<li>In the US, daily vaccination rates are down 19% from a peak, as supply starts to outstrip demand.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A growing chorus of doctors and public-health experts are urging President Joe Biden to donate coronavirus vaccine doses to India, which has rapidly deteriorated into the epicenter of the pandemic. </p><p>India recorded 349,691 new cases on Sunday, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/india-coronavirus-cases-set-new-global-record-us-readies-help-2021-04-25/\">smashing a global record for a fourth consecutive day</a>. Hospitals are being overrun and medical supplies are in short supply. Vaccinations have also been few and far between in the world&#39;s second-most populous country, with <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/covid-vaccine-tracker-global-distribution/?sref=Hhue1scO\">less than 2% of the population fully immunized</a>.</p><p>India provides the most glaring example of the inequity in vaccine distribution, where rich nations have bought up the vast majority of supply. In the US, 53% of all adults have received at least one dose and 36% are fully vaccinated. The rate of infections and deaths have fallen by about 75% since January peaks, and much of the US has already started to reopen. </p><p>Perhaps the sharpest contrast between the two countries is shown in the latest US vaccination figures. The seven-day average of number of shots being given daily in the US is down 17% from a recent peak of 3.35 million. Evercore ISI analysts attribute the decline to &#34;softening demand,&#34; as experts anticipate the US campaign is now inflecting from a supply to a demand challenge.</p><p>Public-health experts and doctors are now urging the US to do much more in assisting India. In particular, they are urging the Biden administration to relax restrictions on exporting raw materials needed for vaccines and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/astrazeneca-coronavirus-vaccine-has-murky-future-in-us-2021-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/astrazeneca-coronavirus-vaccine-has-murky-future-in-us-2021-3\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">to donate doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine</a>, which is not authorized in the US.</p><p>The US government signed a deal with AstraZeneca last summer to eventually deliver 300 million doses of the shot. The US already has <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/us/politics/coronavirus-astrazeneca-united-states.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/us/politics/coronavirus-astrazeneca-united-states.html\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">at least 30 million of those doses on hand</a>, a supply which experts say would be best used by donating to other nations that need it.</p><p>&#34;We need to get these doses donated to countries where supply is limited. Immediately. They do absolutely no good to anyone just sitting on a shelf,&#34; <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Craig_A_Spencer/status/1386168956768108547\">said</a> Dr. Craig Spencer, an assistant professor of emergency medicine at Columbia University&#39;s medical center. &#34;Donating money isn&#39;t enough. Committing to future initiatives isn&#39;t either.&#34;</p><p>In <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/04/24/indias-coronavirus-surge-could-collapse-its-health-system-us-can-help/\">an opinion piece published Saturday in The Washington Post</a>, Dr. Ashish Jha, dean of the Brown University School of Public Health, called for the US to help India scale up testing, establish field hospitals, provide more medical supplies like oxygen, and donate vaccine doses. </p><p>&#34;The United States has strategic interests in helping India weather the pandemic; it is also the right thing to do,&#34; Jha wrote. &#34;Only the United States has the capacity, resources and technical know-how to bend the curve of India&#39;s catastrophic second wave of disease. The faster we assist our ally, the more lives will be saved.&#34;</p><h2>Top US officials respond, vow to take action</h2><p>Under the increased pressure, top US officials have vowed to help India, but details have yet to be made public. </p><p>&#34;Our hearts go out to the Indian people in the midst of the horrific COVID-19 outbreak,&#34; Anthony Blinken, US Secretary of State, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/SecBlinken/status/1386148447179493380\">wrote Saturday night on Twitter</a>. &#34;We are working closely with our partners in the Indian government, and we will rapidly deploy additional support to the people of India and India&#39;s health care heroes.&#34;</p><p>Part of the hesitation in donating vaccine doses has been uncertainty over the viral variants that are present in India, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation&#39;s top infectious-disease expert and Biden&#39;s chief medical advisor.</p><p>Certain variants can partially evade the protection given by vaccines. For instance, AstraZeneca&#39;s shot appeared to be particularly less protective against the B.1.351 variant first identified in South Africa, <a href=\"https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2102214\">according to a 2,000-person clinical trial</a>. </p><p> &#34;They have a situation there where there are variants that have arisen,&#34; Fauci said Friday at a White House COVID-19 task force briefing. &#34;We have not yet fully characterized the variants and the relationship between the ability of the vaccines to protect. But we&#39;re assuming, clearly, that they need vaccines.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-pressured-to-donate-covid-19-vaccine-to-india-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"I visited Downtown Disney a week before Disneyland's reopening and It felt like the safest place I've been since the start of the pandemic","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-disney-disneyland-downtown-covid-safety-california-travel-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>On April 22, I visited Downtown Disney in Anaheim, California, a week before Disneyland&#39;s reopening on April 30.</li>\n<li>Downtown Disney had a long list of health protocols that made it feel fortified against COVID-19.</li>\n<li>The level of safety precautions has me convinced Disneyland will be able to reopen safely. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tDisneyland Anaheim, California's doors have been closed for over a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, while Disney World in Florida has been open since summer 2020.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608240f51041d50019f2dca8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Disneyland California\" height=\"3125\" width=\"4167\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Disneyland in Anaheim, California.\n<p class=\"copyright\">eff Gritchen/MediaNews Group/Orange County Register via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut in March, California announced stadiums and theme parks could open by April 1.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608241d61041d50019f2dcae?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0528\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: </em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disneyland-reopen-date-april-30-2021-3\"><em>Insider</em></a></p>\n\tShortly after, Disneyland said it would be welcoming a limited number of California residents back on April 30.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608241f61041d50019f2dcaf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"disneyland california\" height=\"1499\" width=\"1999\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Abigail Nilsson/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"This is also good news for the Anaheim community, which depends on Disneyland for jobs and business generated by visitors,\"  Bob Chapek, the Walt Disney Company's CEO, said in the annual shareholders meeting on March 9.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082420a4becb800190f6b5a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"disneyland covid\" height=\"2409\" width=\"3212\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Visitors take selfies in front of Sleeping Beauty Castle during the last day before Disneyland closes because of COVID-19 in Anaheim, California on March 13, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Gritchen/MediaNews Group/Orange County Register/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI grew up in Orange County, California, just a 20 to 25 minute drive from the theme park.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47bf12db1ed0002971438e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"disneyland castle selfie\" height=\"717\" width=\"957\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Visitors at Disneyland during the last day Disneyland was open before closing due to COVID-19.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Gritchen/MediaNews Group/Orange County Register via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMy fondness for Disneyland is comparable to that of my affection for In-N-Out: I love them both because they remind me of home and my childhood.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608242581041d50019f2dcb0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0527\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut following Disneyland's reopening announcement in March, I was concerned.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608242924becb800190f6b5b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"disneyland coronavirus vaccines\" height=\"2468\" width=\"3291\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The vaccination line in a parking lot for Disneyland Resort in January.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mario Tama/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHow could a theme park, known for attracting hordes of people, be safe to visit during the coronavirus pandemic?\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608242b81041d50019f2dcb1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"COVID Vaccine Line\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The vaccination line in a parking lot for Disneyland Resort in January.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Valerie Macon/AFP/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI decided to go to Downtown Disney on April 22 - an early Thursday afternoon eight days before the theme park's reopening - to see if the shopping area would give some insight into how safe Disneyland will be once it welcomes guests back.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608242cf1041d50019f2dcb2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0482\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tVisitors have been allowed to stroll around Downtown Disney while the neighboring theme parks have been closed. I hoped if Downtown Disney has strict health protocols, Disneyland's reopening could as well.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082ce691041d50019f2ddf6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"downtown disney\" height=\"1062\" width=\"1417\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/DowntownDisneyCA/photos/a.10150591623751577.372097.195010426576/10150591623766577/?type=3&#38;theater\" target=\"_blank\">Downtown Disney District/Facebook</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI decided to hop into my car on the overcast Thursday afternoon and drove up to Downtown Disney. And upon arriving at the parking lot, I was swiftly reminded of COVID-19 via a large health warning sign.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60823e741041d50019f2dc93?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0096\" height=\"2994\" width=\"3992\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The entrance to the parking lot.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tFrom there, everywhere I looked, I saw another sign or poster reminding visitors of the ongoing health crisis.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082431e1041d50019f2dcb4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0467\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Signs around Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAfter parking my car, I trekked down the path towards Downtown Disney and hit the first two checkpoints: a screening area for temperature checks, and a quick sniff from the security dogs.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082c8311041d50019f2dddb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0472\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The path heading towards the checkpoints.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe temperature check was quick - I was on my way to the next checkpoint within a few seconds.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608243664becb800190f6b5e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0473\" height=\"1110\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The health checkpoint.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tA few feet later, I hit the bag check area.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082437b1041d50019f2dcb5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0570\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The security checkpoint at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe typical health protocols were pretty obvious here: plexiglass shields and masked employees.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608244ae1041d50019f2dcb8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0479\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The security checkpoint.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd after a quick check through my fanny pack and a stroll through the metal detectors, I finally stepped foot in the magically empty Downtown Disney.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608244c74becb800190f6b5f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0553\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOn April 22, Downtown Disney looked like it had lost the spark I remembered from my childhood, solely because it was empty. There were a few families here and there, but no hoards of people on this slightly chilly Thursday afternoon.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60823f934becb800190f6b3f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0494\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs a small child, I remember battling tall adults and crowds just to walk through Downtown Disney with my family. Now, I was free to roam around without fear of colliding with other people.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608240884becb800190f6b4d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0548\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ralph Brennan&#39;s Jazz Kitchen at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDowntown Disney just doesn't feel the same without the high energy that comes with massive crowds of people, but I wasn't upset. An empty Downtown Disney made me feel safe amid COVID-19 concerns.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608244d41041d50019f2dcb9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0491\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd everywhere I looked, I saw a sign or poster reminding visitors of the ongoing health crisis.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082434b4becb800190f6b5d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0498\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The signs around Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThere were reminders of social distancing and face mask-wearing everywhere my eyes darted …\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608244e21041d50019f2dcba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0484\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The security checkpoint.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t… from markers on the floor, to posters on poles, to little signs on the food stands.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608244f34becb800190f6b60?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0557\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The churro stand at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tSome social distancing markers denoting the lines for restaurants and retail stores, such as the World of Disney store shown below, stretched down the length of the storefronts.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608245074becb800190f6b61?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0501\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The signs around Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI decided to take a peek around the World of Disney, and of course, there was a section dedicated to face masks. The store was quietly humming with people, but once again, I didn't see the large crowds I was so used to.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608245144becb800190f6b62?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0508\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A section of masks inside the World of Disney store at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHowever, the long line of social distancing markers outside the store made me wonder just how crowded Downtown Disney can be on the weekend or more popular times.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082452a1041d50019f2dcbb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0483\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The security checkpoint.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut luckily for me, I barely had to worry about the social distancing markers because it was so calm during my visit: only one store had a line in front of it.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082454b4becb800190f6b63?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0566\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The line outside Marceline&#39;s Confectionery in Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd notably, every guest I saw was wearing a face mask. Visitors are allowed to remove their face masks for food or drinks, but it seemed like eagle-eyed workers were on the hunt for any mask-less patrons.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082456a4becb800190f6b64?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0555\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The churro stand at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDuring my stroll through Downtown, I noticed a child who was masked but didn't have their nose covered.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246a04becb800190f6b6a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0562\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWithin seconds of me noticing, a Disney worker walked up to the child and kindly asked them to pull their face mask up over their nose.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608245e61041d50019f2dcbd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0098\" height=\"2716\" width=\"3622\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Disney branded face masks.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI was shocked by the interaction. I didn't expect the workers to be so adamant about the mask-wearing protocol, but I was happily surprised by this diligence and vigilance.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60823e591041d50019f2dc8c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0114\" height=\"2316\" width=\"3088\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Me in Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI noticed several other safety measures besides watchful workers and the sea of signs.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246074becb800190f6b67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0485\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Social distancing signs;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMost surprisingly was several outdoor public sinks that could be seen throughout the premise ...\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246171041d50019f2dcbe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0487\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The hand-washing station.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t... all equipped with a faucet, soap, and paper towels.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082463b4becb800190f6b68?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0520\" height=\"1446\" width=\"1928\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The hand-washing station.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tI've never seen pop-up hand-washing stations before, and while I didn't get the opportunity to use them, I was appreciative of the add-on.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082465b4becb800190f6b69?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0516\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The hand-washing station.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHowever, I only saw one person using the sinks during my stroll around Downtown Disney.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246881041d50019f2dcbf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0535\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Someone using the hand-washing station.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tLike every other public location I've visited during COVID-19, there were plenty of readily available hand sanitizer stations.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246c84becb800190f6b6b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0480\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Hand sanitizer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAnd similar to any eatery these days, most of Downtown Disney's restaurants had plexiglass bearings, distanced tables, and masked workers.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246d51041d50019f2dcc0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0551\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ralph Brennan&#39;s Jazz Kitchen at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs I continued my walk through Downtown Disney, I spotted the gates of Disneyland and California Adventure. But as expected, everything was closed off to the public, and I could only catch glimpses of the theme parks inside.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608246fc1041d50019f2dcc1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0529\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A view into Disneyland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAfter a few laps around the Disney shopping area, I decided it was time to head back home.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608247104becb800190f6b6c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0572\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The security checkpoint at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOverall, the slew of visual reminders for mask-wearing and social distancing, lack of crowds, and vigilant workers made me feel extremely comfortable and safe.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608245b61041d50019f2dcbc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0099\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Marceline&#39;s Confectionery in Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt might have been the safest I’ve felt while out in public during COVID-19.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608247301041d50019f2dcc2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0568\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOf course, this might have been different if I had visited on a Saturday. I did, after all, visit on an early Thursday afternoon just a little over a week before Disneyland's reopening.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082474e1041d50019f2dcc3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0492\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut if the workers are as vigilant on crowded days as they were when I visited, I'm convinced Disneyland might have the chance to reopen safely.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608247611041d50019f2dcc4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0533\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs long as the guests adhere to the theme park's health protocols as well.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6082476d4becb800190f6b6d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0503\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A sign inside a store at the World of Disney store at Downtown Disney.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brittany Chang/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"NASA's Ingenuity helicopter just achieved 'freedom in the sky' in its third aerial adventure over Mars","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-third-mars-flight-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607ce7a044f454001920757d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ingenuity mars helicopter pre flight thumb 2x1\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Left: Ingenuity on the surface of Mars. Right: An illustration of Ingenuity flying.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA/JPL-Caltech/ASU</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-flies-on-mars-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"fd394b7e6cfa4c6eafc0c12aec199a05\">NASA&#39;s Ingenuity helicopter</a> completed its third flight over the Martian surface on Sunday.</li>\n<li>Sunday&#39;s flight likely pushed the helicopter to its farthest distance yet: around 330 feet.</li>\n<li>Ingenuity&#39;s chief pilot said Friday that the helicopter would &#34;experience freedom in the sky.&#34;</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-flies-on-mars-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"fd394b7e6cfa4c6eafc0c12aec199a05\">NASA&#39;s Ingenuity helicopter</a> successfully executed its third flight over the surface of Mars on Sunday.</p><p>The helicopter made spaceflight history last Monday when it lifted off Mars and rose 10 feet above the planet&#39;s surface. Never before had a spacecraft conducted a controlled, powered flight on another planet.</p><p>Then on Thursday, Ingenuity flew even higher - 16 feet - and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-second-mars-flight-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"4f18aa4617067ce02c3d6773b29764f7\">moved sideway</a>s for the first time.</p><p>Sunday&#39;s flight promised to be the helicopter&#39;s most daring excursion yet.</p><p>NASA hasn&#39;t released more detail, but if the flight went <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/post/With%20the%20first%20flight%20of%20Ingenuity%20a%20success,%20we%E2%80%99re%20looking%20toward%20our%20second%20taking%20place%20on%20April%2022,%20which%20is%20the%2018th%20of%20the%2030%20sols%20(Martian%20days)%20of%20our%20flight%20test%20window.\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"d7f7e0af69de65ef6b5eedfae930c5a0\">according to plan</a>, Ingenuity should have reached the same altitude as last time, but increased its maximum airspeed from 0.5 meters per second to 2 meters per second (about 4.5 miles per hour). It likely traveled 50 meters (164 feet) north, then flew back the way it came and landed gently in the copper-colored Martian dust.</p><p>The entire flight should have lasted roughly 80 seconds and covered a total distance of 100 meters (330 feet).</p><p>&#34;Flight three is a big step, one in which Ingenuity will begin to experience freedom in the sky,&#34; Håvard Grip, Ingenuity&#39;s chief pilot, <a href=\"https://mars.nasa.gov/technology/helicopter/status/295/we-are-prepping-for-ingenuitys-third-flight-test/\">wrote Friday</a> before the third excursion. </p><h2>Ingenuity&#39;s team plans to push the helicopter to its limits - even if it crashes</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608197bc4becb800190f688c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ingenuity second flight mars helicopter\" height=\"720\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Perseverance rover captured Ingenuity in mid-air during its second flight on April 22, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/nasas-ingenuity-mars-helicopter-logs-second-successful-flight\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech/ASU/MSSS</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Ingenuity has proven that aerial exploration is possible on other planets, but its mission is far from over. Now NASA wants to gain as much flight data as possible to inform future space-helicopter efforts.</p><p>In up to two more flights over the next two weeks, Ingenuity&#39;s controllers plan to push the helicopter as far and fast as it will go. In the process, they <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-team-push-mars-ingenuity-helicopter-until-crashes-2021-4\">expect Ingenuity will crash</a>.</p><p>&#34;We really want to push the rotorcraft flights to the limit and really learn and get information back from that,&#34; MiMi Aung, the project manager for Ingenuity, said in a recent press briefing.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608343d31d0b54001913db8d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ingenuity flight tracks\" height=\"675\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ingenuity snapped the first color image of the Martian surface taken by an aerial vehicle during its second flight test on April 22, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The fifth and final venture could take Ingenuity laterally across 980 feet of Martian ground, according to NASA&#39;s website. Aung, however, said she would &#34;love&#34; to push it over 2,000 feet.</p><p>By the fifth flight, the helicopter &#34;would be unlikely to land safely, because we&#39;ll start going into un-surveyed areas,&#34; Aung said in a preflight briefing on April 9. </p><p>Speeding up will also challenge the chopper&#39;s mechanics and its navigation system.</p><p>&#34;If we do have a bad landing, that will be the end of mission,&#34; Aung said. &#34;The lifetime will be determined by how well it lands, pretty much.&#34;</p><h2>A looming deadline for the last two flights</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f210e40aee6a81d985b6513?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mars helicopter ingenuity flight nasa gif\" height=\"360\" width=\"640\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An animation of NASA&#39;s Ingenuity helicopter exploring the Martian surface.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://mars.nasa.gov/resources/24935/nasa-mars-helicopter-ingenuity-animations/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JPL-Caltech</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Ingenuity&#39;s flights offer just a peek at the potential of future space helicopters, which could explore parts of Mars and other planets that are inaccessible to rovers. Caves, canyons, mountains, and rocky terrains could all be the domain of a new generation of space-drone explorers.</p><p>But the 4-pound helicopter - roughly the size of a tissue box - is coming up on a looming deadline.</p><p>Preparations and a delay caused by a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-to-update-ingenuity-mars-helicopter-software-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"0ae4dbc4912373b57410f803b3850d56\">software issue</a> consumed the first two weeks of NASA&#39;s 30-day window to conduct up to five flights. Less than two weeks remain before Perseverance - the rover that carried Ingenuity to Mars - has to continue on its main alien-fossil-hunting mission.</p><p>Aung said Monday that there should be enough time to squeeze in all five flights as planned.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-ingenuity-helicopter-third-mars-flight-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
