Shalvey)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/608252df1041d50019f2dcc5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn60@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-56-809_089fe31bbfe6c61f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IScxTDqcfAY:twW4i5L_myo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn39@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-58-236_ab263c15a07dc65d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IScxTDqcfAY:twW4i5L_myo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn52@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-00-204_4ebf04d49fb0339b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IScxTDqcfAY:twW4i5L_myo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn40@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-00-453_c4aae4796cb8c3d4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/IScxTDqcfAY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn71@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-00-506_03350cb805b95523.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596237},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"Kamala Harris says Chauvin verdict 'will not heal the pain that existed for generations'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/harris-chauvin-verdict-will-not-heal-the-pain-that-generations-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6052276dfe6a340019acf1ef?format=jpeg\" alt=\"kamala harris\" height=\"3930\" width=\"5241\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Vice President Kamala Harris speaks on the Atlanta area shootings on March 17, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Vice President Kamala Harris said on Sunday that Derek Chauvin&#39;s trial verdict &#34;will not heal the pain that existed for generations.&#34;</li>\n<li>Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, was <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/derek-chauvin-verdict-george-floyd-death-2021-4\">found guilty </a>of murdering George Floyd.</li>\n<li>On <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CNNSotu/status/1386309377691422720\">CNN&#39;s &#34;State of the Union</a>,&#34; Harris called on Congress to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Vice President Kamala Harris said the <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/derek-chauvin-verdict-george-floyd-death-2021-4\">guilty verdict</a> against former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin is &#34;but a piece of&#34; policing and criminal justice reform. </p><p>&#34;There is no question that we&#39;ve got to put an end to these moments where the public questions whether there&#39;s going to be accountability; questions whether there&#39;s going to be the kind of fairness that we should all expect and deserve in all of our lives and in particular as it relates to people of color,&#34; Harris <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CNNSotu/status/1386309377691422720\">said on CNN&#39;s &#34;State of the Union</a>&#34; Sunday.</p><p>&#34;This verdict is but a piece of it, And it will not heal the pain that existed for generations among people who have experienced and first-hand witnessed what now a broader public is seeing because of smartphones and the ubiquity of our ability to videotape in real-time what is happening in front of our faces,&#34; she said. &#34;And that&#39;s why Congress needs to act, and that&#39;s why they should pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.&#34;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-State of the Union  (@CNNSotu) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1386309377691422720?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 25, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>Last week, Chauvin was found guilty of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and manslaughter for killing George Floyd. Last May, Chauvin was captured on video pinning his knee of Floyd&#39;s neck, sparking anti-racism protests across the country and worldwide. </p><p>&#34;We all watched that video. Many of us watched it multiple times, and people are in pain over what we all saw in that video,&#34; Harris said, adding that &#34;in large part&#34; the case led to the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. </p><p>The House passed the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act in March, which would ban the use of neck restraints at the federal level, get rid of &#34;qualified immunity&#34; for police officers, and prohibit no-knock warrants in federal drug cases, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/house-passes-police-reform-bill-named-for-george-floyd-2021-3\">Insider&#39;s Kelsey Vlamis previously reported</a>. </p><p>&#34;I really do hope that the United States Senate will take it on and have the courage to take it on,&#34; Harris said. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/harris-chauvin-verdict-will-not-heal-the-pain-that-generations-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0KVLvy_dHCQ\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Apr 2021 14:46:18 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60039c27e3d62500185fcf5f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"9f9bc4754bffc8ab854bb1e6c8e57644","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn37@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-54-524_5d36cce85adea471.webp","destWidth":2471,"destHeight":1853,"sourceBytes":122492,"destBytes":122492,"author":"insider@insider.com (Taylor Ardrey)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6052276dfe6a340019acf1ef?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn32@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-54-937_987706ef6880c1c8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn20@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-00-334_e9f34b95aa4efd4e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn28@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-00-023_003d313f92f2b6fb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=0KVLvy_dHCQ:nI0-6IIO0uw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn26@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-02-957_c1659003583c064a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/0KVLvy_dHCQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn22@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-27-02-846_25a0d2622366e2fe.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596200},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"I compared a $5,000 e-bike with a $1,100 one, and saw why it's worth spending more on a premium bike if you can afford it","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/affordable-vs-expensive-electric-bike-comparison-serial-1-rad-power-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fdbdae3c910a400192e8357?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serial 1 14\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>I rode a $5,000 e-bike and a $1,100 model and compared the two. </li>\n<li>The cheaper Rad Power Bikes RadMission 1 is a great bike for the money. </li>\n<li>But the Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed has better parts and a smoother ride, making it well worth its $5,000 price tag. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Before I took the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/serial-1-e-bike-review-harley-davidson-electric-commuter-cty-2020-12\">$5,000 Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed</a> from Harley-Davidson for a spin, I figured that high-end e-bikes - like most upmarket products - were all flash and no substance. </p><p>Boy was I wrong. </p><p>No doubt, a more budget-friendly e-bike like the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rad-power-bikes-radmission-1-review-best-affordable-e-bikes-2021-1\">$1,099 RadMission 1</a> from Rad Power Bikes gets the job done, and then some. The RadMission gets you to all the same places as a pricier bike in just about the same amount of time and looks decent doing it. It even has thoughtful features like built-in lights and a bell. </p><p>But shelling out the extra $3,900 for the Rush/Cty Speed - coming this summer - can pay off for those who can afford it. </p><h2><strong>What you get</strong></h2><p>The RadMission comes with everything you need and nothing you don&#39;t: A hub motor, disc brakes, a decent-sized battery, ergonomic grips, confidence-inspiring knobby tires, and plenty of mounting points for Rad Power Bikes&#39; accessories like racks and fenders. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6083357808610f0018b0f3d7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RadMission 9\" height=\"1549\" width=\"2065\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>RadMission 1.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>But Serial 1 equipped its top-of-the-line model with tons of high-end, well-thought-out components you just can&#39;t get on a budget bike. The philosophy behind many of the company&#39;s design choices was to make the bike as maintenance-free as possible. </p><p>For example, the Rush/Cty Speed makes use of a belt drive rather than a conventional chain, delivering a quieter ride and eliminating the need to clean, lubricate, or replace a chain. The bike gets its stopping power from hydraulic disc brakes, which means no potential for cables that slack over time and need adjustment. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fdbd66dc910a400192e833f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serial 1 9\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Other nice touches include built-in racks, a be-seen light built into the front badge, a bright headlight mounted to the handlebars, and brake lights embedded into the back of the frame. There&#39;s also a lockable storage cubby that&#39;s designed to fit a folding bike lock. </p><h2><strong>Looks</strong></h2><p>Looks are subjective of course, but I think the Rush/Cty has the edge here. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60146d22d6c5e60019c6e038?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RadMission 5\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>RadMission 1 e-bike.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Instead of a bulky battery pack mounted to the downtube, Serial 1 models get their power from a battery that slots into the frame between the pedals. That battery pack - which uses the same technology as Harley&#39;s LiveWire electric motorcycle - is removable, so riders can charge up without lugging the whole bike inside. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fdbe159c910a400192e8373?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serial 1 15\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Whereas the RadMission has a somewhat unsightly nest of cables up front running to the brakes, battery, and controller box, on the Serial 1, there&#39;s barely a cable in sight. That&#39;s because Serial 1 routed the bike&#39;s brake cables and other wiring internally through the frame. That&#39;s not all that functional, but it contributes to the Rush/Cty&#39;s sleek look. </p><h2><strong>The ride</strong></h2><p>Both the RadMission 1 and the Rush/Cty Speed have four levels of pedaling assistance, but that&#39;s where the similarities end when it comes to how these bikes ride. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60146d23d6c5e60019c6e039?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RadMission 10\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>RadMission 1.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The RadMission 1 has a basic setup of a hub motor powering the rear wheel and a sensor that switches the power on when the rider starts pedaling. That&#39;s similar to what&#39;s found on most low-end electric bikes, and it certainly gets you where you need to go. </p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/europe-could-derail-harley-davidsons-post-trump-comeback-2021-4\">A new tariff fight in Europe could derail Harley-Davidson&#39;s triumphant comeback after its war with Trump</a></em></p><p>The Rush/Cty Speed benefits from a much more advanced drivetrain that combines a torque-sensing mid-drive motor with an automatic Enviolo Nuvinci transmission. In plain English, that means the motor registers the effort a rider puts in and helps out accordingly; the harder you pedal, the more assistance you get. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fdbdeabd366e60018098cbf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serial 1 16\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Business</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>That&#39;s happening while the continuously variable transmission constantly - almost imperceptibly - reacts to keep you in the right gear. </p><p>The combination of those two systems means all you have to do is select a pedal-assist level, and the Rush/Cty smoothly takes care of the rest. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60146d226dfbe10018e00d8f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RadMission 6\" height=\"2015\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>RadMission 1 e-bike.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Speed isn&#39;t purely a factor of cost, but it&#39;s worth mentioning that the RadMission&#39;s claimed 20-mph top speed left me wanting at times. The Rush/Cty Speed tops out at 28 mph, making it easier to keep up with traffic and catch green lights.</p><p>Not to mention, the Rush/Cty&#39;s mid-drive motor and battery placement give it a low center of gravity, making it feel remarkably balanced and planted, even at high speeds. </p><h2><strong>Final thoughts</strong></h2><p>There&#39;s no question - for most people, $5,000 is a lot to spend on a bike. </p><p>But e-bikes have the potential - even more so than regular bikes - to replace car trips altogether for many people in many places. And when you consider that the price of the average new car sold in the US has ballooned to nearly $40,000 - and that a solid used car can run you well over $10,000 - spending a few thousand dollars on a highly capable e-bike starts to sound a lot more reasonable.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6083395b5f61100018270fe2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Serial 1 Rush/Cty Speed.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Levin/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Plus, legislation may be on the way that would <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/electric-bike-tax-credit-proposal-house-democrats-2021-2\">slash the price of e-bikes</a> through a tax credit like the one that currently exists for buyers of electric vehicles. </p><p>In the meantime, if you can&#39;t shell out for the Rush/Cty Speed, Serial 1 has a handful of lower-priced options with many of the same features. And regardless of how it stacks up to Rush/Cty Speed, the RadMission 1 remains one of the best affordable e-bikes on the market. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/affordable-vs-expensive-electric-bike-comparison-serial-1-rad-power-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=uJzzKn4atQ4:y2NdRtoDVhM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=uJzzKn4atQ4:y2NdRtoDVhM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uJzzKn4atQ4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Apr 2021 12:53:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60833a381d0b54001913db7c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"2c6bdd9dfd25e4c942a95e0769ece53b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn81@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-54-596_673a623e84236b98.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":395244,"destBytes":395244,"author":"tlevin@businessinsider.com (Tim Levin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fdbdae3c910a400192e8357?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn95@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-55-512_394916fb353f3aa1.webp","https://i.insider.com/6083357808610f0018b0f3d7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn47@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-57-588_ae5928160aed9d05.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fdbd66dc910a400192e833f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn52@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-02-660_d7bc826fb5482d3b.webp","https://i.insider.com/60146d22d6c5e60019c6e038?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn91@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-02-676_16aee01ad8c70df1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fdbe159c910a400192e8373?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn60@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-26-59-505_abd14eec2c15444a.webp","https://i.insider.com/60146d23d6c5e60019c6e039?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn52@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-55-207_95964013575b06a5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fdbdeabd366e60018098cbf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn1@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-01-533_a3ceffaf0b633cab.webp","https://i.insider.com/60146d226dfbe10018e00d8f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-59-318_633b4c6adc6da0a2.webp","https://i.insider.com/6083395b5f61100018270fe2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-58-548_56299f8ba4274dc2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uJzzKn4atQ4:y2NdRtoDVhM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn93@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-03-690_e32ce0cb583fa830.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uJzzKn4atQ4:y2NdRtoDVhM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn48@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-00-538_36b8eec13be6fb28.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uJzzKn4atQ4:y2NdRtoDVhM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn69@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-01-395_6c68c8236e855a76.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uJzzKn4atQ4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn96@2020_5/2021/04/25/17-27-03-249_34ac6bcf78225226.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596229},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"Biden's sanctions targeting Russia's cyber behavior could backfire on the US","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-sanctions-on-russian-cyber-behavior-could-backfire-for-us-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/54c176a76da811b81225717d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Vladimir Putin\" height=\"1709\" width=\"3418\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Yuri Kochetkov/Pool </p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Biden administration imposed imposing economic sanctions on Russia for an act of cyber espionage - the SolarWinds attack.</li>\n<li>From an international law perspective, the move is controversial and could potentially come back to bite the US in the future.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Last week, the Biden administration took the bold step of imposing economic sanctions in response to an act of cyber espionage, namely the SolarWinds attack.</p><p>It seems that the new US administration is finally getting serious about standing up to Russian aggression in cyberspace. But from the perspective of international law, the move is controversial and could potentially come back to bite the US in the future, given its own cyber capabilities.</p><p>The release of the Executive Order announcing the sanctions, which also respond to Russian meddling in the 2020 US presidential elections and other actions, coincided with a call between President Joe Biden and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, in which the two leaders discussed the possibility of a summit on arms control.</p><p>In this context, the sanctions can be understood as a symbolic show of strength amid parallel moves to deescalate tensions and rebuild trust and respect in the wider bilateral relationship.</p><p>Nevertheless, the reprisals represent <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/stakes-high-expectations-low-trump-putin-meet-helsinki/story?id=56603366\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a clear break from the Trump administration</a>, during which a serving US president cast doubt on his own intelligence services&#39; assessments regarding Russian disinformation, electoral interference and other cyberattacks.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/15/fact-sheet-imposing-costs-for-harmful-foreign-activities-by-the-russian-government/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">measures announced last week</a> include the imposition of economic sanctions barring US financial institutions from purchasing Russian sovereign debt, as well as the expulsion of 10 Russian diplomats.</p><p>The SolarWinds compromise, in which hackers introduced malware to a wide range of networks through a security update to SolarWinds&#39; network-monitoring Orion platform, was uncovered in December 2020, after having been in operation for up to nine months.</p><p>It was described at <a href=\"https://www.bankinfosecurity.com/senators-push-for-changes-in-wake-solarwinds-attack-a-16409\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a US Senate intelligence hearing last week</a> as one of the largest and most sophisticated cybersecurity breaches in history. Known victims include the US Department of Homeland Security, NATO, the European Parliament and a handful of UK targets, as well as many private-sector businesses and organizations using the Orion platform.</p><p>The inclusion of the SolarWinds attack as a cause for the announced sanctions is a new and creative attempt to raise the cost of Russia&#39;s brazen and destructive activities in cyberspace, something Western democracies have struggled to do in recent years. Until now, they have resorted to &#34;naming and shaming,&#34; which has yielded mixed results.</p><p>In October 2018, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-45746837\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the US and its allies coordinated among themselves</a> to publicly denounce Russian attempts to hack into the networks of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and various anti-doping agencies, as well as other cyberattacks they attributed to Russia.</p><p>It was an impressive show of solidarity and combined intelligence capabilities, but whether it had the desired deterrent effect is less than clear. It may have perversely fed the harmful narrative of Russia&#39;s strength at cyber dirty tricks.</p><p>The embarrassing discovery of the SolarWinds breach highlights that for Russia, cyber business continued as usual.</p><p>The Biden administration&#39;s announcements last week are significant for two reasons.</p><p>First, they represent the first official public attribution by US intelligence services of the SolarWinds compromise to the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service, or SVR. That&#39;s in line with a growing trend in which states use such attribution strategically, to make sure bad actors know they are not evading scrutiny.</p><p>Second, the eye-catching inclusion of SolarWinds in the Executive Order is controversial from an international law perspective. The expulsion of diplomats and imposition of sanctions are classic examples of &#34;retorsion,&#34; located at the lower end of the lawful responses reserved by states that are victims of another state&#39;s breach of international law.</p><p>This is significant because despite its audacity and scale, SolarWinds was a classic case of espionage. The attackers did no damage. They just installed themselves in their victims&#39; systems and soaked up information. When discovered, they withdrew. For national security and international lawyers, the invocation of an act of espionage as a breach of international law is unconvincing at best.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd88b3d2069f400194c7c3a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin shakes hands with U.S. Vice President Joe Biden during their meeting in Moscow March 10, 2011.\" height=\"747\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Vladimir Putin, then Russia&#39;s prime minister, with Joe Biden, then US vice president, at a meeting in Moscow, March 10, 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Alexander Natruskin</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>There is no doubt that Russia&#39;s reckless, almost anarchistic behavior in cyberspace merits a strong response from the US and its allies. But last week&#39;s Executive Order and accompanying documents are light on international law analysis, and that&#39;s probably a deliberate choice.</p><p>In the past, Russia&#39;s other egregious acts - such as the use of the chemical nerve agent Novichok in the attempted assassinations of Alexei Navalny and Sergei Skripal, or its cyberattacks on critical infrastructure in Ukraine - have clearly crossed the international law threshold for retorsion.</p><p>But the US, alongside the UK and other states that have broad-spectrum capabilities in cyber, has until now been careful to carve out espionage from the scope of the sovereignty principle under international law, although this is often couched in such ambiguous and complex language that one could be forgiven for missing it.</p><p>This explains why Michael Hayden, a former US director of national intelligence, went so far as to describe China&#39;s notorious hacking of a US government personnel database, discovered in 2015, as &#34;<a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2021/04/15/joe-biden-seeks-to-clobber-russia-with-new-economic-sanctions\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">honorable espionage work</a>.&#34;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/23738871.2020.1832550\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">In an article published in October in the Journal of Cyber Policy</a>, which I edit, Chatham House&#39;s Harriet Moynihan explained that while several states, such as the Netherlands, France and Austria, consider that an unauthorized cyber incursion by one state into another could in certain circumstances be a violation of the principle of state sovereignty, that has not been the consensus view.*</p><p>Moynihan told me more recently that, based on the current facts, she is doubtful the SolarWinds hack violated international law.</p><p>Last week&#39;s Executive Order and the papers accompanying it announce that the US will be working to incorporate like-minded allies, including the UK, France, Denmark and Estonia, into joint cyber exercises to reinforce their shared commitment to collective security in cyberspace.</p><p>But in order for these like-minded countries, particularly the US, to shape future norms for responsible state behavior in cyberspace, they will need to bring nonaligned swing states along with them. To do so, Ciaran Martin, former head of the UK&#39;s National Cyber Security Centre, told me, &#34;The US will have to work harder to convince swing states that it is really committed to achieving fair and balanced rules of the road.&#34;</p><p>Seen in this light, the inclusion of an act of cyber espionage, SolarWinds, as a justification for international law responses may do more harm than good, given Washington&#39;s own cyber intelligence activities.</p><p>Another intriguing aspect of last week&#39;s Executive Order is whether the economic sanctions it imposes will actually hit Russia where it hurts - in the wallet. Lord Peter Ricketts, a former UK national security adviser, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/LordRickettsP/status/1382962338140205056\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">praised the US action</a> as an &#34;asymmetric&#34; approach &#34;to remind Russia of their econ[omic] weakness.&#34;</p><p>But, after causing a &#34;<a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/bb555605-1c1e-4144-bc99-d05b58dc61d7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">brief wobble</a>,&#34; the sanctions don&#39;t seem to have had much long-term impact on the markets, suggesting that they may be more symbolic in nature, rather than a real attempt to destabilize the Russian economy.</p><p>In the wider context, as the new US administration sets out its Russia policy more clearly, last week brought us <a href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/04/13/readout-of-president-joseph-r-biden-jr-call-with-president-vladimir-putin-of-russia-4-13/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a show of strength and resolve on cyber, coupled with an olive branch</a> in the area of traditional arms control: a proposed summit between the two leaders to &#34;build a stable and predictable relationship consistent with US interests.&#34;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/trend-lines/29581/will-tense-us-russia-relations-impede-cooperation-on-arms-control\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">In a Trend Lines interview with WPR&#39;s Elliot Waldman last week</a>, Sarah Bidgood, the director of the Eurasia Nonproliferation Program at the James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies, described the risks to national and international security of today&#39;s US-Russia relationship, characterized as it is by &#34;real acrimony ... a lack of respect for one another that permeates all aspects of the relationship.&#34;</p><p>The proposed summit is an urgently needed attempt to restabilize the relationship with Russia and prevent the risk of escalation and mutual harm. That difficult, but positive engagement could be an opportunity for Russia to play a more responsible role in its future use of cyber technologies.</p><p><em>*Editor&#39;s note: This sentence was revised to more precisely reflect the positions of the three states named.</em></p><p><em>Emily Taylor is the CEO of Oxford Information Labs, and an associate fellow with the International Security Program at Chatham House. She is also the editor of the Journal of Cyber Policy, a research associate at the Oxford Internet Institute, and an affiliate professor at the Dirpolis Institute at the Sant&#39;Anna School of Advanced Studies in Pisa. She has written for The Guardian, Wired, Ars Technica, the New Statesman and Slate. Follow her on Twitter <a href=\"https://twitter.com/etaylaw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@etaylaw</a>. Her guest column will appear each Tuesday.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a <li>Furniture, outdoor decor, and bikes were nearly out of stock everywhere I went.</li> \n <li>COVID-19 and the Suez Canal blockage have disrupted the global supply chain and changed demand.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n  Empty and picked-over shelves have become commonplace at some retailers. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608084abc36a8a00185c63fc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" difficult for brick-and-mortar retailers to keep shelves stocked. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608086b04becb800190f65c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" see how locations were impacted. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608086e64becb800190f65cb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n src=\"https://i.insider.com/608186344becb800190f681d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Home decor and outdoor furniture areas looked especially sparse. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608186b1354dde0018c069b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Any kind of seating and cushions were almost completely wiped out. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60805b8f44f4540019208012?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The empty space isn't surprising - \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60805b9344f4540019208015?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> - home decor and outdoor furniture sales have exploded over the last year as people have been mostly stuck at home because of the pandemic. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60818b2e354dde0018c069d2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/home-decor-sales-are-booming-target-homegoods-amid-the-pandemic-2020-8\">Insider</a></em></p> Furniture has also been affected by the weeklong blockage of the Suez Canal and congestion at other ports, leading to wait times of several months in some cases. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608198244becb800190f688f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/toilet-paper-coffee-products-delayed-suez-canal-blockage-impact-2021-3\">Insider</a></em></p> Other outdoor recreation items also had empty spaces on shelves. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60818e394becb800190f6858?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Despite having an entire wall display, there were almost no bikes on the floor, and only a few helmets. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60805b8e74da0300181e2ffe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Target empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Next up, I visited Burlington Coat Factory. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60805d434becb800190f64f5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Burlington Coat Factory empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> As a discount store, I was prepared for some messy shelves and disorganization. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60818f954becb800190f6860?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Burlington Coat Factory empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The store definitely had plenty of empty shelf space. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60818fc5354dde0018c069f9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Burlington Coat Factory empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The store is in a giant warehouse, though, so it felt like the space was just too big for what the store had to sell, rather than real shortages. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60818fe8354dde0018c069fa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Burlington Coat Factory empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Shelves that seemed empty because they'd been picked over were mostly in home decor sections, much like Target. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608190294becb800190f6866?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Burlington Coat Factory empty shelves\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Marshall's had some empty shelf space, but nothing too shocking. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081a6ad4becb800190f68f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marshall's empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Summer necessities like beach towels and chairs seemed most affected. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081a6d4354dde0018c06a93?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marshall's empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> There were some stray pieces of luggage without a display. Maybe the rest were all bought up as people anticipate traveling again. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081a6f3354dde0018c06a95?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marshall's empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Walmart had both empty shelves and messy, overstocked areas when I visited. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819154354dde0018c06a07?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Several aisles looked like they served almost as dumping grounds for whatever didn't have a place elsewhere. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608191a1354dde0018c06a09?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The clothing section was one of the most disorganized. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608192e1354dde0018c06a0c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Like at Target, furniture options were slim and looked very picked over. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608191f94becb800190f686a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Desks, a must-have in a year of working from home, were mostly gone. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608192194becb800190f686b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Even less expensive home decor items like pillows were in short supply. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608192794becb800190f686c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Like Target, outdoor products at Walmart seemed to be most affected by shortages. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819320354dde0018c06a0f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Empty Walmart shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Bike racks were nearly empty. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819316354dde0018c06a0e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Empty Walmart shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> The pandemic shut down the supply chain for bikes while also increasing demand, leading customers to pay two to three times more in some cases. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819b544becb800190f68a9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Empty Walmart shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-bike-shortage-panic-buying-bicycles-2020-10\">Insider</a></em></p> Helmets aren't much easier to find, either. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608081cdc36a8a00185c63e4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Empty Walmart shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> All kinds of outdoor toys seemed to be out of stock ahead of summer. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819c3a4becb800190f68ae?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Empty Walmart shelves\" height=\"2803\" width=\"3737\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Tools like leaf blowers and saws were in short supply at Walmart. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819c764becb800190f68b2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> Many people have invested time and money into improving their outdoor living areas, creating shortages in outdoor decor along with furniture. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819d24354dde0018c06a58?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/17/outdoor-furniture-sales-grow-as-customers-prepare-for-a-summer-at-home.html\">CNBC</a></em></p> Grills, which analysts predict will continue to be popular this summer, were also in short supply. That combined with a possible hog meat shortage could impact summer barbecue plans. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60819dea354dde0018c06a59?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_6259\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bacon-hot-dog-shortages-trade-supply-2021-4\">Insider</a></em></p> Even gardening supplies have been affected in a \"nationwide plant shortage.\" \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081a49b4becb800190f68e2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/chattanooga-area-garden-centers-finding-210000349.html\">Yahoo News</a></em></p> The National Retail Foundation says that spending will likely shift from goods to services as COVID-19 restrictions are lifted, which could alleviate some of the strains on the supply chain. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/608083114becb800190f65ac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-expensive-goods-supply-shortage-congested-shipping-ports-texas-freeze-2021-3\">Insider</a></em></p> Goldman Sachs analysts predict supply chain disruptions will continue until at least early 2022. \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081a5a34becb800190f68ec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Walmart empty shelves\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-expensive-goods-supply-shortage-congested-shipping-ports-texas-freeze-2021-3\">Insider</a></em></p>\n <p><em>Do you have a story to share about a retail or restaurant chain? 69db6.webp","https://i.insider.com/6081a5a34becb800190f68ec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn98@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-923_2aec9247dc1ca48f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L_yctBqRaBc:P3dowYMhdTg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn52@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-27-00-531_027e94a990cc2a84.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L_yctBqRaBc:P3dowYMhdTg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn90@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-02-223_36942e06bc0d957c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L_yctBqRaBc:P3dowYMhdTg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn23@2020_1/2021/04/25/17-26-58-623_e3b47b4ff9e5b05c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L_yctBqRaBc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn52@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-27-00-862_b88297c7b474b3e6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596246},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"Chicken wings are in short supply nationwide due to Texas storms and soaring demand for the 'pandemic-proof' delicacy","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/chicken-wing-short-supplies-demand-texas-storms-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6083313908610f0018b0f3bb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chicken wings Anchor Bar Buffalo\" height=\"1191\" width=\"1589\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A plate of wings at Anchor Bar in Hamilton, Ontario.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rick Madonik/Toronto Star via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Restaurants nationwide are facing a tight supply of chicken wings. </li>\n<li>The scarcity is due to soaring demand, plus the Texas winter storms, which impacted flocks.</li>\n<li>One restaurant CEO said wing prices are the highest they&#39;ve been in his 33 years in the business.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Chicken wings are the latest hot-ticket item to face tight supply as a result of the pandemic. </p><p>Restaurants across the nation are reporting a scarcity of wings and rising costs per pound, the result of a spike in take-out orders and the unprecedented winter storms in Texas. It&#39;s leading some restaurants to raise prices for customers, and others to worry that they won&#39;t be able to meet demand. </p><p>The tight supply is being felt acutely in Buffalo, New York - the home of the humble chicken wing.</p><p>Duff&#39;s, a wing restaurant known for its extremely hot wings with legions of diehard fans, told <a href=\"https://www.wivb.com/news/local-news/buffalo/national-chicken-wing-shortage-continues-to-hurt-restaurants/\">Buffalo&#39;s CBS affiliate WIVB</a> that its seen a spike in take-out orders - about 60% of one location&#39;s business comes from take-out orders, versus 40% prior to the pandemic.</p><p>Jeff Feather, a manager at a Duff&#39;s location, told WIVB that the restaurant is having a difficult time securing enough cases of flats and drumsticks to get through the weekend.</p><p>&#34;Say we order 50 cases of wings to get us through the weekend. We might only get 30 of them delivered. So we&#39;re getting about two-thirds of what we typically order,&#34; he said. &#34;There are some days our food reps will call us and say we might not be able to get you anything.&#34;</p><p>Feather told WIVB that wings cost the restaurant $3 per pound, and each case weighs roughly 40 pounds.</p><p>While a chicken wing shortfall is likely to hit Buffalo hard, other regions nationwide are noticing a wing deficiency as well. Moe Stevenson, Virginia-based restaurant owner, <a href=\"https://www.wivb.com/news/national/theres-a-national-chicken-wing-shortage/\">told WIVB</a> that the cost of drums - a wing shape <a href=\"https://www.thrillist.com/eat/nation/best-chicken-wing-parts-drums-flats\">some people seem to prefer</a> - has increased threefold since last year to the tune of an extra $1,200 per week. Stevenson called the price increase &#34;outrageous.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I thought it would drop off after the Super Bowl, like it usually does, March Madness, it&#39;s done,&#34; he said. &#34;No, it&#39;s gone up.&#34;</p><p>Dan Ponton, CEO of an Ohio-based wing chain called Roosters, <a href=\"https://www.daytondailynews.com/local/on-a-wing-and-a-prayer-chicken-wing-shortage-pinches-dining-experiences-local-and-national/7WMAUZ3GTFA33BUDSWW2RE4DDU/\">told the Dayton Daily News</a> that he hasn&#39;t noticed a shortage of other chicken parts, like breasts or tenders - but wings are a different story.</p><p>&#34;The prices are the highest they have ever been in the 33 years I&#39;ve been doing this,&#34; he said. </p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-to-pursue-damages-from-tyson-pilgrims-pride-2021-4\" data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\">McDonald&#39;s will pursue damages from Tyson and Pilgrim&#39;s Pride in chicken price-fixing scandal</a></em></p><h2>Wings are &#39;pandemic-proof&#39;</h2><p>Tom Super, a spokesperson for the National Chicken Council, told Insider by email that while wing supplies are tight, he wouldn&#39;t call the situation a shortage. Super blamed the short supply on the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/winter-snow-storm-blackout-texas-damages-could-near-50-billion-2021-2\">winter storms that struck Texas</a> earlier this year.</p><p>&#34;Chicken producers are doing everything they can to overcome the devastating impact of Mother Nature when she inflicted the once-in-a-lifetime winter storm on Texas and nearby states - major chicken producing regions,&#34; Super said. &#34;It will take time and effort to eventually replace the impacted hatchery supply flocks in that region.&#34;</p><p>Super said that chicken production has remained steady in 2020 and described the deep-fried delicacy as &#34;pandemic proof&#34;: Most wing joints or pizza places already had takeout infrastructure in place, so they were able to continue operating for most of last year.</p><p>Wings also travel well, they&#39;re comfort food, and they&#39;re easy to cook up at home, Super said. </p><p>&#34;As long as people are sitting around watching TV and maybe drinking a beer, wings will remain in the game. Don&#39;t forget the <a href=\"https://www.grubstreet.com/2020/12/why-america-is-still-obsessed-with-air-fryers.html\">air fryer revolution</a>, either,&#34; he said. &#34;Bottom line - wing demand has been high.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/chicken-wing-short-supplies-demand-texas-storms-2021-4'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/72tUwmRAPBM\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Apr 2021 13:45:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6083313908610f0018b0f3bb?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"176a7af487ea99269a0df3a8ab0a4598","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-46-048_050a62254159c577.webp","destWidth":1589,"destHeight":1191,"sourceBytes":166620,"destBytes":166620,"author":"ahartmans@businessinsider.com (Avery Hartmans)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6083313908610f0018b0f3bb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-26-46-048_050a62254159c577.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn49@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-27-01-639_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn6@2020_2/2021/04/25/17-27-03-720_dc3808f5950036e3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn80@2020_6/2021/04/25/17-26-56-204_1d597f1fc5d8bc6a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-58-549_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=72tUwmRAPBM:uHr2ZdBvq5Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn10@2020_4/2021/04/25/17-27-01-609_698f07837660a8b9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/72tUwmRAPBM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn15@2020_3/2021/04/25/17-26-55-023_20d71aed56f03e2f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1619371596204},{"createdTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"There's a simple solution for companies struggling to hire: Pay workers more","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/labor-shortage-solution-pay-workers-higher-wages-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6081bd204becb800190f6991?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chipotle\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Fast-food chains are struggling to hire. The solution is to pay workers more.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"http://pictures.reuters.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Fred Prouser/Reuters</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>There&#39;s an obvious fix for all the business owners who cannot find workers: pay more.</li>\n<li>As companies scramble to address labor shortages, experts say higher pay is the only real solution.</li>\n<li>Some businesses will close, but that is part of a functioning free market system.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As a former manager of a Chipotle in West Virginia, Chris Drown knows <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-pays-50-for-job-interviews-highlighting-hiring-struggles-2021-4\">how hard it is to hire employees. </a></p><p>&#34;We had plenty of applicants, but anyone we hired would quit because the wages we were offering were far too low compared to the stress of the crew positions,&#34; Drown recently told Insider. </p><p>Employees were driven away by long, stressful shifts, and those who took mandated breaks were considered &#34;lazy,&#34; Drown said. Understaffing was a constant issue, as employees who were paid roughly $10 an hour scrambled to clean and chop sufficient ingredients to keep food on the line, he said. </p><p>Drown decided it was time for him to quit his $15-per-hour job after ice storms pummeled West Virginia in February. According to Drown, he was expected to show up to work despite icy road conditions. When the ice melted, roads began to flood. </p><p>&#34;I contacted the field leader and told him we needed to close early, my staff feels unsafe,&#34; Drown said. &#34;It was expected that even if I was there by myself, I would have to keep the store open until close no matter what.&#34;</p><p>&#34;So I closed the store, went home, and never came back,&#34; said Drown, who is now working in retail. </p><p>Drown is one of the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Annahoj737/status/1385111945536327687\">many</a> workers responding to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-subway-struggle-to-find-workers-forcing-changes-2021-4\">companies&#39; recent complaints</a> about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-unemployment-benefits-fuel-hiring-struggles-companies-say-2021-4\">hiring struggles</a> with a simple demand: Improve working conditions, or pay us more.</p><p>As companies <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-subway-struggle-to-find-workers-forcing-changes-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\">scramble to cut hours and change operations,</a> some experts also recommend raising wages, saying it could provide a more permanent solution to the worker shortage. </p><p>&#34;You couldn&#39;t pay me $20 an hour to work in food for the conditions we had to endure there,&#34; Drown said. &#34;After I left that location, five more people quit. Now, they are operating with online orders only and limited hours because they still can&#39;t keep up.&#34; </p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/subway-franchisees-say-risks-associated-with-investing-chain-2021-4\">Subway&#39;s &#39;dirt-cheap&#39; startup costs are a huge draw, but franchisees and experts say investing comes with big risks</a></em></p><h2><a data-e2e-name=\"inline-read-more-link\"></a>Higher pay is one of the only real solutions to the hiring shortage</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607f3fc844f4540019207d42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"now hiring\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Companies are facing a labor shortage, despite a 6% unemployment rate.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Nam Y. Huh</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Experts say that a number of factors are making it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fast-food-struggles-to-hire-as-demand-soars-us-economy-roars-2021-4\">difficult for companies to hire,</a> despite an unemployment rate of 6%.</p><p>Enhanced unemployment benefits, workers&#39; concerns about catching COVID-19, and the rapid reopening of businesses are all cutting into the number of potential candidates. Even before the pandemic, many lower-paying jobs were struggling to hire. </p><p>&#34;We&#39;re going to go back to that really competitive marketplace for labor,&#34; said Marc Wulfraat, the president of logistics consulting firm MWPVL. </p><p>&#34;It&#39;s going to be a shock to companies that are paying low wages,&#34; Wulfraat added. &#34;They&#39;re going to be the ones that are hit the worst, because all that low-wage labor is going to find a home elsewhere - where there&#39;s more money to be made.&#34;</p><p>People looking for jobs increasingly have options that pay at least $15 an hour at industry giants like Starbucks, Amazon, and Target. They may also be able to find jobs that offer greater flexibility than traditional retail jobs, such as driving for Lyft or delivering food for UberEats. </p><p>Credit Suisse analyst Lauren Silberman told Insider that companies are going to have to improve their pay, benefits, and culture to combat hiring difficulties. Companies&#39; values are increasingly important to workers, Silberman said, making a chain like Starbucks that has invested in building a reputation of social consciousness potentially more attractive to workers than some of its fast-food rivals. </p><p>Employers told Insider they are already looking into offering new benefits and higher pay. Blake Casper, who owns 60 McDonald&#39;s locations in Florida, said that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-pays-50-for-job-interviews-highlighting-hiring-struggles-2021-4\">he is considering raising starting wages from $12 to $13 per hour.</a> Dunkin&#39; franchisee John Motta said that it is already impossible to hire people at minimum wage. </p><p>&#34;I wouldn&#39;t have anybody at my store if I was paying at $7.25,&#34; Motta said. &#34;The minimum wage is pretty much dictated, in my opinion, by the marketplace.&#34; </p><h2>Some businesses will be forced to close. That&#39;s not a bad thing.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fce3ec6eadd8400183df70b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Friendly&#39;s restaurant closed\" height=\"1356\" width=\"2712\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Not every store or restaurant is going to survive.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jonathan Wiggs/The Boston Globe/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Employers are quick to say that higher wages will create new problems. </p><p>Companies usually offset higher wages by passing costs along to customers. In the restaurant industry, for example, minimum wage regulation typically leads to higher menu prices. This week, Chipotle CFO Jack Hartung said that a $15 federal minimum wage <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/chipotle-will-raise-burrito-prices-if-a-15-minimum-wage-passes-2021-4\">would mean a slight increase in burrito prices.</a> (Chipotle did not respond to Insider&#39;s request for comment on Drown&#39;s experience working at the chain.) </p><p>&#34;Ultimately in any business, the customer pays for everything,&#34; Waffle House CEO Walt Ehmer told Insider in November. &#34;We don&#39;t have any other source of revenue other than the customer. So, we have to be careful how we treat our customers and we don&#39;t stick it to them with giant price increases.&#34;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/waffle-house-ceo-slams-lockdowns-keeps-dining-rooms-open-2020-11?r=kt-sub\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1b38071f8ef3d90855f0a78e664d807e\">Waffle House reveals why it will never shut down indoor dining again unless it&#39;s forced to, as the CEO takes a stand against lockdowns</a></em></p><p>Motta and other franchisees expressed concerns that higher prices would drive away customers and hurt business. But, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/15-minimum-wage-higher-menu-prices-waffle-house-potbelly-2020-11\">executives at chains including Kura Sushi, The Cheesecake Factory, and Texas Roadhouse </a>have said that, so far, customers have adjusted to higher menu prices related to higher pay. </p><p>Not every business can afford to raise wages to compete with companies like Amazon and Target that already pay at least $15 per hour.</p><p>Wulfraat said that some companies will try and replace some workers with automation, but that can be an expensive investment. Some will be forced to close, even after surviving the COVID-19 pandemic. </p><p>&#34;How are businesses that struggled during the pandemic, that were barely able to stay open now, being asked to pay people more money?&#34; said Ryan Alovis, the CEO of LensDirect.</p><p>&#34;Those people don&#39;t even want to show up to work, because they may actually be making more money at home than they will going to work,&#34; Alovis added, referring to enhanced unemployment benefits. &#34;We&#39;re in a scary cycle.&#34; </p><p>Businesses closing because they cannot afford to meet workers&#39; demands is part of a healthy free market system, experts say. </p><p>Analysts have been warning for years that there are too many <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/24/perspectives/retail-2020\">stores</a> and <a href=\"https://www.providencejournal.com/entertainmentlife/20190806/there-are-too-many-restaurants-food-industry-experts-say--poll\">restaurants</a> in the US, with supply outpacing demand. <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/newsletters/five-things/latest\">Joe Weisenthal wrote in</a> Bloomberg Markets&#39; newsletter on Thursday that the tight labor market will help roots out &#34;zombie companies&#34; that are doomed in a truly free market. </p><p>&#34;And so now we might find out who the real zombies companies were - the companies that were only able to succeed due to cheap labor caused by a precarious market, and thus bringing the economy down as a whole,&#34; Weisenthal writes. </p><p>Drown said his time at Chipotle helped him come to a similar conclusion. </p><p>&#34;My opinion is that restaurants will only succeed if they are staffed properly and pay enough to meet the stress of it all,&#34; Drown said.</p><p>&#34;Without having both, turnover will keep going up,&#34; he continued. &#34;Slim staffing is really hurting restaurants, and that&#39;s the main reason we are seeing the whole industry struggle to meet demand.&#34;</p><div 01:26:36","updatedTime":"2021-04-26 01:26:36","title":"Indonesia says missing submarine has been found broken into pieces deep in the ocean","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/missing-indonesia-submarine-found-broken-into-pieces-deep-in-ocean-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60820c004becb800190f6ac9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Indonesia submarine\" height=\"809\" width=\"1619\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An KRI Nanggala-402 submarine owned by Indonesia, the same model as the one that went missing on Wednesday.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Widojo/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The missing Indonesian submarine has been found, according to Indonesian military officials.</li>\n<li>The vessel is reportedly deep in the ocean and broken into multiple pieces.</li>\n<li>&#34;It can be stated that the KRI Nanggala has sunk and all of its crew have died,&#34; one official said.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Indonesia submarine that went missing this week has been found shattered into several pieces deep in the ocean, the Indonesian military said Sunday.</p><p>&#34;We received underwater pictures that are confirmed as the parts of the submarine,&#34; Indonesian military chief Hadi Tjahjanto said. The photos were taken by an underwater robot deployed from a Singaporean vessel, <a href=\"https://www.whsv.com/2021/04/25/indonesia-admits-all-53-crew-of-lost-submarine-are-dead/\">according to the Associated Press</a>.</p><p>The Indonesian military, supported by international assets, has been searching tirelessly for the KRI Nanggala 402 and its crew since it disappeared north of the island of Bali during a training exercise Wednesday.</p><p>Search teams found an oil slick suggesting a possible fuel tank rupture early in the search, and then more recently, they discovered items that appeared to have come from inside the vessel, such as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/indonesia-submarine-missing-vessel-presumed-sunk-after-debris-found-2021-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"c0404f0ec33d7f8971f7ed21dbd93733\">prayer rug pieces, a bottle of periscope lubricant, part of a coolant pipe, and a torpedo component</a></p><p>&#34;With the authentic evidence we found believed to be from the submarine, we have now moved from the &#39;sub miss&#39; phase to &#39;sub sunk,&#39;&#34; Indonesian Navy Chief Yudo Margono said at a press conference Saturday.</p><p>At that press event, Margono also revealed that a sonar scan detected an object believed to be the missing submarine at a depth of almost 2,790 feet. At that depth, which is well beyond the vessel&#39;s maximum depth, the hull of the submarine would not have been able to withstand the crushing water pressure.</p><p>On Sunday, Margono announced that the submarine had been found and confirmed the previous day&#39;s assumptions.</p><p>&#34;The KRI Nanggala is divided into three parts, the hull of the ship, the stern of the ship, and the main<a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/indonesian-president-sends-condolences-families-sunken-submarine-crew-2021-04-25/\"> parts are all separated, with the main pa</a>rt found cracked,&#34; Margono said Sunday, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/indonesian-president-sends-condolences-families-sunken-submarine-crew-2021-04-25/\">according to Reuters</a>.</p><p>&#34;Based on the evidence, it can be stated that the KRI Nanggala has sunk and all of its crew have died,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/indonesian-president-sends-condolences-families-sunken-submarine-crew-2021-04-25/\">Tjahjanto said</a>. The submarine was carrying 53 passengers at the time it disappeared.</p><p>The loss of KRI Nanggala 402 and all 53 lives on board <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sinking-indonesian-naval-submarine-worst-submarine-disasters-2021-4\">puts this deadly tragedy among some of history&#39;s worst submarine disasters,</a> incidents like the sinking of ARA San Juan and the loss of 44 Argentine sailors just a few years ago.</p><p>&#34;All of us Indonesians express our deep sorrow over this tragedy, especially to the families of the submarine crew,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/indonesian-president-sends-condolences-families-sunken-submarine-crew-2021-04-25/\">Indonesian President Joko Widodo said Sunday</a>, sending his condolences to families of the sailors lost aboard the sunken submarine.</p><p>Although there are theories, such as a power failure preventing the submarine from resurfacing after experiencing some sort of emergency situation, it is unclear exactly what happened to the KRI Nanggala 402 submarine at this time.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original
